Here is a Theory perhaps Tim can look into this. I noticed that the fire almost appeared to get fed by the water instead of it going out. Looking up interactions between methane and  water there really isn't any UNLESS water is in the gaseous form... which does tend to happen when you spray it onto a fire. At that point the mixture of the two produces hydrogen... which tends to be explosive. So if you have a fire because of a methane leak... don't put it out with water. I don't know but it sounds plausible.

Yes definitely looked like a fuel line purge to me. Also known in the industry as a 'methane burp'. Of course there is no oxydizer so it burns using the oxygen in the air, hence the huge fireball.

Obviously it's not supposed to produce this fireball but because the vehicle was still somewhat on fire, it ignited. This is similar to the fuel line purge fire seen on the last failed landing of a falcon 9 booster (the one with the stalled grid fins, can't remember the mission)
